title: Tom Brady shows support for Patriots ahead of Super Bowl LX after saying he ‘doesn’t have a dog in the fight’
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Tom Brady initially stated he wasn't supporting the Patriots in Super Bowl LX, citing no "dog in the fight."
Brady later expressed backing for Patriots owner Robert Kraft via an Instagram post, urging him to "get that 7th ring."
Former Patriots, including Vince Wilfork, criticized Brady's initial comments due to his Raiders ownership stake.

title: Former Colts Pro Bowl center thinks Drake Maye should have won NFL MVP over Matthew Stafford
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Matthew Stafford beats Drake Maye for NFL MVP with a narrow six-point margin.
Jeff Saturday believes Drake Maye deserved NFL MVP over Matthew Stafford due to Maye's dual-threat capabilities.
ESPN's Mina Kimes highlights Maye's superiority in key statistics, criticizing Stafford's win despite his impressive passing yards.

title: 5 X-factors for Patriots, Seahawks in Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots plan to target Seahawks QB Sam Darnold with blitz-heavy defense in Super Bowl LX showdown.
Seattle defense, first in scoring and EPA, faces challenge from Patriots QB Drake Maye's scrambling ability.
Patriots linebacker Robert Spillane's ankle injury could impact their run defense against Seattle's rushing attack.

title: Patriots get good Drake Maye news on final injury report, but 2 captains are listed as questionable
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Quarterback Drake Maye has no injury designation and is expected to play in the Super Bowl.
Patriots' linebackers Harold Landry and Robert Spillane are questionable for the Super Bowl due to knee and ankle injuries.
Rookie defensive lineman Joshua Farmer and Seahawks' fullback Robbie Ouzts are both questionable for Sunday's game.

title: 5 must-watch movies & TV shows streaming right now
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: 'Hell or High Water,' a contemporary Western by Taylor Sheridan, is now streaming on Netflix.
'Splitsville,' a 2025 romantic comedy, is available to stream on Hulu.
The 2026 Winter Olympics are streaming on Peacock, with events available on the Gold Zone feature.

title: ‘We all we got, we all we need’: How Stefon Diggs’s  voice sparked a New England rallying cry
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Stefon Diggs's phrase 'we all we got, we all we need' has become a rallying cry for the New England Patriots.
The Patriots adopted the phrase during a turnaround season, winning 15 of their last 16 games after a 2-2 start.
Despite facing legal issues, Diggs remains a key leader for the Patriots as they prepare for Super Bowl LX.

title: She’s running her first-ever marathon to raise money for Mass. General Hospital
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Armanda Demeris, 34, from North Attleboro, is running her first Boston Marathon to benefit Massachusetts General Hospital Fund.
Funds raised will support emergency preparedness, cancer care, and the Home Base Program for veterans.
Demeris' ties include her emergency nurse friend, breast cancer survivor mother, and veteran husband.

title: Foodie’s Markets to close South End location, resulting in neighborhood outcry
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Foodie's Markets will close its South End location in June after 28 years, citing high update costs.
The Croft School planned to occupy the space but withdrew due to community opposition.
Over 1,500 residents signed a petition to preserve the space as retail or food-use instead.

title: The anonymous Drake Maye Lover Instagram account has developed quite the following
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: The anonymous Instagram account @DrakeMayeLover started in May 2024 and has nearly 400,000 followers.
Drake Maye, quarterback for the New England Patriots, is aware of the account and its meme-filled posts.
The account owner is anonymous but plans to reveal identity after taking a photo with Maye.

title: Tom Brady’s Super Bowl LX neutrality strikes a nerve with Patriots fans
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Tom Brady's neutrality on the Patriots-Seahawks Super Bowl LX game has upset many New England Patriots fans.
Nearly 700 respondents weighed in, with opinions split between disappointment, understanding, and indifference regarding Brady's comments.
Fans feel conflicted as Brady transitions from Patriots icon to a neutral figure due to his new broadcasting career and Raiders ownership.
